articles.headline: TD Bank to Acquire Commerce
articles.snippet: For Toronto-Dominion, the deal to buy Commerce Bancorp provides another way for the Canadian bank to overcome limited growth opportunities at home.
articles.abstract: For Toronto-Dominion, the deal to buy Commerce Bancorp provides another way for the Canadian bank to overcome limited growth opportunities at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Oct. 2 — Commerce Bancorp agreed to accept a $8.5 billion offer from Toronto-Dominion Bank on Tuesday, three months after the removal of its maverick founder, Vernon W. Hill II, made the sale of the company inevitable.

articles.headline: Hedging Their (Political) Bets
articles.snippet: On Wall Street, writing checks to political candidates can be as much about doing favors for friends and business associates as supporting deeply held political beliefs.
articles.abstract: On Wall Street, writing checks to political candidates can be as much about doing favors for friends and business associates as supporting deeply held political beliefs.
articles.lead_paragraph: JASON H. WRIGHT, a senior executive at Merrill Lynch, is a passionate Democrat and an active fund-raiser for Senator Barack Obama. He also sits on Mr. Obama’s national finance committee.

articles.headline: Scrutiny for Insurers of the Aged
articles.snippet: The top-ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee has asked 11 long-term care insurance companies to explain “troubling data” regarding how policyholders’ claims are handled and paid.
articles.abstract: The top-ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee has asked 11 long-term care insurance companies to explain “troubling data” regarding how policyholders’ claims are handled and paid.
articles.lead_paragraph: The top-ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee has asked 11 long-term care insurance companies to explain “troubling data” regarding how policyholders’ claims are handled and paid.

articles.headline: From Errand to Fatal Shot to Hail of Fire to 17 Deaths
articles.snippet: New details have emerged on an episode involving a Blackwater USA convoy that killed 17 people and left 24 wounded.
articles.abstract: New details have emerged on an episode involving a Blackwater USA convoy that killed 17 people and left 24 wounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Oct. 2 — It started out as a family errand: Ahmed Haithem Ahmed was driving his mother, Mohassin, to pick up his father from the hospital where he worked as a pathologist. As they approached Nisour Square at midday on Sept. 16, they did not know that a bomb had gone off nearby or that a convoy of four armored vehicles carrying Blackwater guards armed with automatic rifles was approaching.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Unlike U.S., Japanese Push Fiber Over Profit
articles.snippet: Japan is a broadband paradise with the world’s fastest and cheapest Internet connections, but some analysts wonder if the country’s push to install fiber is worth the effort.
articles.abstract: Japan is a broadband paradise with the world’s fastest and cheapest Internet connections, but some analysts wonder if the country’s push to install fiber is worth the effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The United States may be the world’s largest economy, but when it comes to Internet connections at home, many Americans still live in the slow lane. By contrast, Japan is a broadband paradise with the fastest and cheapest Internet connections in the world.

articles.headline: In the Clouds, Sitting Watch Over Paradise
articles.snippet: Mike Gates has been a fire lookout, a sky-high voyeur in the battle against wildfires, for the last 21 years.
articles.abstract: Mike Gates has been a fire lookout, a sky-high voyeur in the battle against wildfires, for the last 21 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON SADDLEBACK MOUNTAIN, Calif. — Walk into Mike Gates’s summer home here and the first thing you notice — the only thing you could possibly notice — is the view.

articles.headline: When 2 Is Bigger Than 48
articles.snippet: The economies of New Hampshire and Iowa are not similar to the rest of America, a fact that can’t help but skew the political debate.
articles.abstract: The economies of New Hampshire and Iowa are not similar to the rest of America, a fact that can’t help but skew the political debate.

articles.headline: Swedish Smokeless Tobacco Aims at U.S. Market
articles.snippet: The American tobacco industry is looking to snus - moist ground tobacco that users tuck between the cheek and the gum - as a potentially profitable alternative to cigarettes.
articles.abstract: The American tobacco industry is looking to snus - moist ground tobacco that users tuck between the cheek and the gum - as a potentially profitable alternative to cigarettes.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 27 — Cooling his heels outside a popular nightclub here recently, Jesper Froberg stubbed out his cigarette and reached for a less harmful pleasure: smokeless tobacco, neatly packed in tiny pouches that look like miniature used tea bags.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: After the Party
articles.snippet: In a market gone sour, the messy business of buyouts puts reputations on the line.
articles.abstract: In a market gone sour, the messy business of buyouts puts reputations on the line.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR the last few years, deal makers have been popping Champagne corks and swinging from chandeliers. Now they are popping aspirin and sweeping up the pieces.

articles.headline: Clinton Steals Obama’s Fund-Raising Thunder
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign said it had beaten Senator Barack Obama in donations since July.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign said it had beaten Senator Barack Obama in donations since July.
articles.lead_paragraph: A major dynamic behind the fight for the Democratic presidential nomination — fund-raising — shifted yesterday as Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign announced that it had beaten Senator Barack Obama in donations since July, stripping him at least temporarily of a crucial political advantage.
